seed: I keep overthinking everything at work, and I'm scared I'm going to get fired even though nobody said anything.

transcript.content: I keep overthinking everything at work, and I'm scared I'm going to get fired even though nobody said anything.

It sounds like you're feeling a lot of pressure about what might happen at work, even without any direct feedback.  What kinds of things are you finding yourself thinking about when you feel this way?

Yeah, I guess I do feel a lot of pressure. It’s like I’m constantly worrying that I’m not doing enough, you know? Sometimes I think about how my boss might be disappointed or if my coworkers are judging me. It's exhausting. I can’t shake this feeling that if I slip up just once, everything could go really wrong.
It sounds like when you imagine a misstep, your mind jumps to a very significant outcome. What kind of impact do you think that "everything going wrong" would have on your life?

Honestly, it feels like it would be catastrophic. Like, if I mess up at work, I could lose my job and then everything else would fall apart—my finances, my relationships. I’d be a complete failure. It’s hard to even visualize that happening without feeling this weight in my chest. It's as if one mistake could unravel everything I’ve worked for.
It sounds like you're anticipating a very specific outcome from a potential mistake at work. What other possibilities might exist besides the worst-case scenario?

I don’t know… I guess I could just fix the mistake or learn from it, right? But it’s hard to even think like that when I’m in the moment. My mind just jumps to the worst possible thing. It's like I shut down and can’t see any other way things could go. I suppose I just feel like I have to be perfect all the time, and anything less
It sounds like there's a lot of pressure to control the outcome when things don't go as planned. What makes you think that being perfect is the only acceptable option in these situations?

I think it’s just… I’ve always felt like I had to prove myself, especially growing up. I was always compared to others, and it felt like if I wasn’t the best, I just didn’t matter. So now, at work and in life, I guess I equate my worth with how well I perform. If I’m not perfect, then what am I, you know
It sounds like there's a strong belief that your value is directly tied to your achievements.  What makes you think that being "the best" or "perfect" is the only way to be worthwhile?

It’s just how it’s always been for me. I remember my parents—achievements seemed to be the only thing they really cared about. I guess I internalized that, thinking that if I didn't excel, I wouldn’t be loved or accepted. I just can’t shake it off. When I think about not being the best, it feels like that would mean I’m not enough. It

It sounds like there's a strong connection between your parents' emphasis on achievements and how you view yourself.  What do you think might happen if you were to explore those feelings of "not being enough" beyond just academics?

I’m not sure, honestly. It’s kind of scary to think about. If I start digging into those feelings, what if I uncover more about myself that I don’t like? I mean, if I recognize I’m not living up to some ideal, it might just make everything worse. I guess I’m afraid of what it might mean for my relationships or how I see my life. I

It sounds like you're anticipating a potential shift in your understanding of yourself and its impact on your connections with others.  What kind of "ideal" are you considering, and how might recognizing a difference from that ideal affect your view of those relationships?

Yeah, it feels pretty daunting to think about. The ideal is like this perfect image of someone who’s always put together, successful, and never messes up. If I start realizing that I fall short of that, I wonder if my friends and family would change how they see me. Like, would they be disappointed? Would they pull away? It’s terrifying to think that could happen just because
It sounds like you're connecting your sense of self-worth to an external standard.  What evidence do you have that people would react negatively if you didn't meet this ideal?

I guess I don't have solid evidence, but it's just a feeling I’ve carried for so long. I’ve seen friends and coworkers get praised or rewarded for their success, and I sometimes feel like that’s the only way to get approval. I imagine they’d look at me differently if I wasn’t keeping up, like maybe I wouldn’t belong anymore. It’s like this fear that if I’m

It sounds like you're connecting your sense of belonging with external validation. What makes you think that others would view you differently based on achievements rather than who you are as a person?

I mean, I think it’s just what I’ve seen growing up. People seem to get more attention or affection when they succeed; I’ve always noticed that. It’s like if you’re not winning, you’re just… invisible. So, when I mess up or don’t hit those marks, it feels like I slip into the background. I can’t help but think that if they can

It sounds like your experiences growing up have shaped a belief about how people are treated based on their achievements.  Have you considered whether there might be other ways people show attention and affection besides through success?

Yeah, I’ve thought about it. I mean, I see how some people connect through support and just being there for each other, not just through accomplishments. But it’s easier said than done for me. When I see someone else succeeding, it pulls me back to that old way of thinking. I guess I struggle to believe that people would care about me just for being myself and not for what
